:droid: *<https://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v4/app/ServiceCompat.html?hl=PL|ServiceCompat>*: _START_STICKY. int START_STICKY. Constant to return from onStartCommand( Intent, int, int) : if this service's process is killed while it is started (after returning ..._
:droid: *<https://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Build.VERSION_CODES.html|Build.VERSION_CODES>*: _onStartCommand function will return the new START_STICKY behavior instead  of the old compatibility START_STICKY_COMPATIBILITY . int, ECLAIR_0_1._

<@U25CTHVN0>  regarding the GPS service, I know the service will be killed due to many reason while the app in the background it fully depend on the android process manager, but what we end up doing is that whenever the onDestroy() or onTaskRemoved() get called we relaunch the service..
make sure to put some logic their to avoid relaunching it when you actually wanted to kill the service

How can i put action  bar there ?
<@U25CTHVN0> you are thinking about this wrong
think of a toolbar like you would a more flexible actionbar
you supply one yourself
and put it where ever you want
so if you want the next activity to have a toolbar/nav drawer
just put it there

okay.
thanks nish

:droid: *<https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/resources/providing-resources.html|Providing Resources>*: _Whereas XML resource files in other res/ subdirectories define a single resource  ... For instance, you should include alternative drawable resources for different ..._

What does the ‘debuggable’ gradle attribute actually change? (Other than making an app debuggable)
I’m trying to debug a broken feature which works on debug mode, but fails on release mode with the exact same explicitly defined attributes.
Turning on debuggable for release actually makes the broken feature work… until debuggable is disabled again. :stuck_out_tongue:
As much as I know (which isn't a lot) - allows for app process to be seen in DDMS and for debugger to be attached
That wouldn’t explain why a complete view just vanishes from the app as soon as it’s built without debuggable set to true… This is getting incredibly silly.
Proguard config problems?
Nah I just figured it out
Someone configured the encryption keys wrongly that were supposed to be used in release mode :stuck_out_tongue:
for requests
so release mode debuggable still puts the apk in ‘debug’ mode apparently.

:droid: *<https://developer.android.com/guide/topics/connectivity/nfc/nfc.html|NFC Basics>*: _This document describes the basic NFC tasks you perform in Android. It explains  how to send and receive NFC data in the form of NDEF messages and ..._

your counter var should be in the data model

You are stating that the variable will never change

```
final int var = 5;
var = 6; // Error!
```
